plants.name: Iris germanica
plants.description: A hardy perennial with large, showy flowers that come in a variety of colors including purples, blues, yellows, and whites. It has sword-shaped leaves and is a popular garden plant.
plants.location: Temperate gardens worldwide, especially North America and Europe
plants.funFact: The Bearded Iris gets its name from the fuzzy 'beard' on the petals, which helps attract pollinators.

plants.name: Jacaranda mimosifolia
plants.description: A deciduous tree known for its stunning display of vibrant lavender-blue trumpet-shaped flowers covering the canopy. It blooms profusely in spring, creating beautiful purple carpets when petals fall.
plants.location: Subtropical regions such as southern USA, South America, Australia, and South Africa
plants.funFact: Jacaranda trees are often called the 'Lord Mayor's tree' as they are widely planted in urban areas for their spectacular floral display.

plants.name: Erythronium hendersonii
plants.description: A wildflower native to the western United States with nodding, delicate flowers that are typically a rich purple or pink with yellowish tips. It emerges early in the spring before the forest canopy fully develops.
plants.funFact: Fawn lilies get their name because their leaves are mottled like a fawnâ€™s coat, which helps them blend into the forest floor.

plants.name: Camellia japonica
plants.description: An evergreen shrub that produces large, waxy flowers often blooming in late winter to spring. Flowers can be single or double and appear in colors ranging from white to deep red.
plants.location: East Asia, also cultivated in temperate gardens worldwide
plants.funFact: Camellias have been cultivated in Japan and China for centuries and are highly prized for their elegant flowers and glossy leaves.
